entry.title: How to Get Remaining Balance for Specific Line Item of an Invoice or Advance
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I‚Äôm trying to get a report in SAP that shows the remaining balance against a particular line item of an invoice or advance payment.

I have already tried the following:

  • J3RFPCR ‚Äì This only shows the original payment document for Special G/L indicator ‚ÄòA‚Äô (Down Payments) but not for other types of transactions.

  • S_ALR_87012105 ‚Äì This doesn‚Äôt provide the line-item level remaining balance information I‚Äôm looking for.

üëâ Internally, the system is working correctly ‚Äì when I run F-53 (Post Outgoing Payment), SAP perfectly shows how much balance is left against that line item and how much I have already adjusted. But I need a report or transaction to view this information directly without going into F-53.

What I need is:

‚úÖ A standard report or method to get the remaining open amount for each line item in an invoice/advance (not just at header level).
‚úÖ Ability to see it for all Special G/L indicators, not just for ‚ÄòA‚Äô.

Is there any:

  • Standard report or transaction code?

  • Table combination or query that can achieve this?

  • Or do I need to go for a custom report? - I have tried table level but didn't get it, BSE_CLR, BSEG

Any suggestions or best practices would be highly appreciated.

Thank you!

entry.title: Using SAP hana-client promises module with TypeScript
entry.content:
Hi all,

I've been using @SAP/hana-client Promises module for many years. A new project is being written on TypeScript, and importing "@sap/hana-client/extension/Promise.js" leads to message "Could not find a declaration file for module '@sap/hana-client/extension/Promise.js'. '(...)/node_modules/@sap/hana-client/extension/Promise.js' implicitly has an 'any' type.
If the '@sap/hana-client' package actually exposes this module, try adding a new declaration (.d.ts) file containing `declare module '@sap/hana-client/extension/Promise.js';". This makes type inferrence impossible on the downstream, so we need to manually type each variable/function declaration to not be of type any.
As @SAP/hana-client has a .d.ts file, I would expect the Promises module to be typed, but then it would probably be imported from the root of the module (as usual with any other lib), instead of being imported directly from the specific .js file.


With that context, I have 2 questions:
1) How/where can I raise an issue to the appropriate SAP team to have this correctly typed (and, even better, importable from the root)?
2) Is there a way we can "type the Promises module ourselves" (via type coercion from the types made available by @SAP/hana-client or something in that sense), so that types can be inferred as expected?

 

Thank you in advance,

Lawisch

entry.title: "Camel execution failed‚Äù Error on Fiori Registration (Only in Production) / Impact of Variable Table
entry.content:
Title:

‚ÄúCamel execution failed‚Äù Error on Fiori Registration (Only in Production) / Impact of Variable Table Reference?

Question:

‚ñ† Overview

In our Fiori application, an error occurs when clicking the Register button on a transactional entry screen.
The same code works fine in the test environment, but fails in the production environment.

‚ñ† Environment Setup (Simplified)

  • CDS view is used to read cost department master data (name anonymized)
  • Backend is Node.js, accessing CDS via CAP service
  • The CDS view references a table, passed via variable in the service

‚ñ† Environment Differences

The referenced table has a higher record count in production (e.g. test: 3,000 records, production: 3,500 records).
CDS view definitions and service logic are identical across environments.

‚ñ† Error Message (Excerpt)

 
[SqlError: internal error: Camel execution failed. Reason: Cannot process result] { code: 403, sqlState: 'HY000' }

We noticed the generated SQL contains something like JSON_TABLE('{}'), which may be contributing to the failure when handling empty JSON input under certain conditions.

‚ñ† Code Example (with variable table name)

Here is the original code using a variable for the table name:

 

 
const result = await this.tx.run(
    SELECT.one.from(table).where(conditions)
);

This code causes a 403 error only in the production environment.

‚ñ† Temporary Fix (working version)

When we explicitly provided the table name as a string, the issue was resolved:

const table = 'Z_ACTUAL_COST_DEPT_MASTER'; // ‚Üê anonymized actual table name const result = await this.tx.run( SELECT.one.from(table).where(conditions) );

‚ñ† Questions

  1. What could be the root cause of the Camel execution failed. Reason: Cannot process result error in this context?
  2. Could the use of JSON_TABLE('{}') in the CDS-generated SQL cause issues in production due to volume or empty JSON input?
  3. Is it possible that using SELECT.from(variable) in CDS behaves differently across environments (e.g. due to view resolution)?
  4. Are there any best practices for safely referencing tables via variables in CDS views, especially for production stability?

‚ñ† Notes

  • Table names and record counts are anonymized.

  • I can provide HANA version and CDS definitions if needed.

entry.title: Node.js @sap/hana-client 2.25.29 getting strange errors on Windows
entry.content:
Since the Node.js @SAP/hana-client version 2.25.29 with @SAP/cds I am getting strange errors on Windows (Linux works fine) like this:

TimeoutError: ResourceRequest timed out
    at ResourceRequest._fireTimeout (node_modules\generic-pool\lib\ResourceRequest.js:62:17)
    at Timeout.bound (node_modules\generic-pool\lib\ResourceRequest.js:8:15)

and when using it together with @SAP/hdi-deploy I get errors about SAP Crypto lib that is missing:

Detection of server version failed; root cause: Connection failed (RTE:[300005] SAP crypto lib is not available: Exception caught in CommonCryptoLib::getInstance (127.0.0.1:53059 -> xxx:443))

When using the previous version 2.25.22 on Windows, it works fine. Can it be that there is something wrong with the native prebuilt binaries for the new version on Windows?

entry.title: what side effects dose seperate business partner code for each customer and vendor have in sap s4han
entry.content:
Hi All,

I'm currently working on s/4 hana conversion PJT as BP Consultant.
(ECC 6.0 EHP 8.0 -> S/4 HANA)

The thing is that i have decided to create bp code for each customer and vendor which means we don't make use of CVI system in new system. because the utility of customer/vendor code is low also, the code have been created via external system - MDM from vendor/customer ( not sap user inside our customer). additionally, the factor our customer worried about the most by converting to S/4 hana is to re-create whole customer/vendor code system matching with Business Partner (the as-is number range for customer and vendor  overlapped already and they have any specific rule of creating code for each account group)

what i worried about is that as far as i understand the credit management and TR module is the things affected by BP. Is there any else i couldn't noticed yet? 

hope get a response from sap guru..

thanks in advance.

entry.title: SAP Factory Calendar Synchronization Use Case
entry.content:
Overview

In SAP implementations, the Factory Calendar (TFACD table) plays a critical role in scheduling and planning processes, particularly for manufacturing businesses with Make-to-Order (MTO) scenarios. This use case highlights the importance of timely synchronization of the Factory Calendar between SAP ECC, BW, and HANA systems to ensure accurate production scheduling and order tracking, avoiding significant business disruptions.

Business Scenario

A manufacturing organization relied on an SAP-based order tracking application to manage MTO processes. The application used SAP HANA Calculation Views and Table Functions to calculate order availability dates by combining the production order schedule finish date with goods receipt processing days, factoring in only working days as defined in the Factory Calendar (TFACD).

Challenge

In 2022, the Factory Calendar in the SAP ECC system was updated to reflect temporary changes in working days due to external circumstances, marking Fridays as non-working days (TFACD FRTAG = 0). This configuration was successfully replicated to the BW and HANA systems at the time. However, in late 2023, the organization updated the ECC Factory Calendar to reinstate Fridays as working days (TFACD FRTAG = 1). Due to an oversight, the "Transfer Global Settings" process was not executed, resulting in a discrepancy between the ECC, BW, and HANA systems.

This misalignment caused the order tracking application to inaccurately calculate order availability dates. For instance, when an availability date fell on a Thursday, the system incorrectly extended it to the following Monday, assuming Friday was a non-working day. This led to significant frustration among business users, who observed delays in order scheduling, impacting operational efficiency and customer satisfaction.

Initially, the issue was misdiagnosed as a flaw in the HANA Calculation View logic. However, thorough analysis revealed that the root cause was the failure to synchronize the updated Factory Calendar across all systems.

Solution

The issue was resolved by executing the "Transfer Global Settings" process to synchronize the Factory Calendar (TFACD) from SAP ECC to the BW and HANA systems. This action updated the working day configuration, aligning all systems with the correct schedule.

Outcome

  • Resolution Time: The synchronization process resolved the issue in approximately 10 minutes, addressing a problem that had persisted for nearly two years.
  • Business Impact: Accurate order availability dates restored user confidence in the system, improved production scheduling, and enhanced customer satisfaction.
  • Lessons Learned:
    • Timely synchronization of the Factory Calendar across SAP systems is critical for accurate scheduling and reporting.
    • Regular validation of global settings replication can prevent discrepancies in cross-system processes.
    • Collaborative root cause analysis is essential to avoid misdiagnosing issues as logic errors when they stem from configuration mismatches.

Best Practices

  1. Automate Global Settings Transfer: Schedule periodic execution of the "Transfer Global Settings" process to ensure consistency across SAP ECC, BW, and HANA systems.
  2. Monitor Factory Calendar Updates: Implement governance to track and communicate changes to the Factory Calendar, ensuring all relevant systems are updated promptly.
  3. Cross-System Validation: Perform regular checks to validate data consistency between ECC, BW, and HANA, particularly for critical tables like TFACD.
  4. User Feedback Loop: Encourage business users to report anomalies in scheduling or reporting, enabling faster identification of system discrepancies.

Conclusion

This use case underscores the importance of maintaining synchronized configurations across SAP systems to support critical business processes. By prioritizing timely updates and proactive monitoring, organizations can avoid operational disruptions, enhance system reliability, and ensure a seamless user experience.

The above mentioned use case was real life business problem encountered by the team and resolved.

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud - SUM of Subtotals is not matching the Total
entry.content:
Hi all,

I'm building a dashboard in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) using a live connection to an SAP HANA view. I have an issue that when results are presented for multiple Org Units the SUM of the Subtotals (for each Org Unit) is not matching the overall Totals (for all Org Units). 

The underlying data model contains daily records that could be simplified into these fields:

  • Date (attribute)
  • FTE (measure ‚Äì stable over time)
  • Quota (measure ‚Äì may change daily)
  • Org Unit (attribute with hierarchy)

If an Org. Unit doesn't have a Quota value for a specific day, there is no record at all for that day and the row is missing (not NULL or 0).

In SAC model I have added date hierarchy (Year-Quarter-Month) based on the Date field and created a calculated measure TotalFTE = FTE * Quota to display the TotalFTE month by month on the dashboard.

However, when aggregating TotalFTE by Org Unit at the daily level, I found that Org Units with incomplete daily records had inconsistent results as their denominator was not matching denominator of Org Units with complete daily records.

For example:

  • If Org Unit A had had records for only 15 days in a 30-day month the denominator was 15: TotalFTE(Subtotal A) = FTE*Quota/15.
  • Org. Unit B with complete records for the whole month (30 days) had the denominator as 30: TotalFTE(Subtotal B)=FTE*Quota/30.

This then resulted that the SUM of Subtotals (Subtotal A + Subtotal B) were not matching the Totals: TotalFTE(A+B)=FTE(A+B)*Quota(A+B)/30, as the denominators were not the same.

When trying to fix this, I enhanced the HANA view to include:

  • A Month column (derived from Date)
  • A CountMonthDays field (the number of calendar days in each month, e.g. 31 for March)

I then updated the SAC formula to normalize against the number of days in the month: TotalFTE = FTE * Quota / CountMonthDays to have the same denominator.

This worked well at the monthly level ‚Äî Subtotals and Totals aligned correctly.

However, the problem reappears when:

  • Aggregating by Quarter or Year
  • Users apply filters for custom time ranges (e.g. Jan‚ÄìMay)

Since some Org Units don‚Äôt have records for every Month in the selected period, their TotalFTE is divided by fewer days due missing months (e.g. only 90 instead of 151), while the total uses the full range (e.g., 151 days), causing Subtotals ‚â† Totals again.

Thanks in advance for any ideas or experience with this issue!

entry.title: Unable to generate reports using MC.1

entry.title: Hi All I want to start learning ABAP on Hana which practice system I can opt
How to Extract Complete Organizational Structure Across SAP Modules (MM, FI, CO, PM, etc.)
entry.content:
Hello Experts,
We are looking for guidance on how to extract or download the complete organizational structure from our SAP system, including details from all relevant modules such as SAP MM (Materials Management), PM (Plant Maintenance), FI (Financial Accounting), CO (Controlling), and others.

Our goal is to obtain a comprehensive dataset or report that reflects the full organizational hierarchy and configuration details across all implemented modules.

Could you please advise if there is a standard SAP transaction, report, tool, or recommended methodology to accomplish this?
